intro: Acacia notabilis, commonly known as the golden wattle, is a shrub or small tree native to Australia. It is characterized by its feathery, bipinnate leaves and produces yellow globular flowers that bloom in spring. The plant is well adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, showcasing drought tolerance and efficient water use. Its root system helps prevent soil erosion, making it ecologically significant in its native habitat. The golden wattle is also a symbol of Australia and is widely cultivated for ornamental purposes.

Its family is Fabaceae, commonly known as the legume family, characterized by pod fruits and nitrogen-fixing abilities. Its genus is Acacia, a large group of shrubs and trees known for their acicular leaves and often used for timber or as ornamental plants. Its species is Acacia notabilis, a specific type of acacia found in certain regions, distinguished by its unique morphology and ecological adaptations.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia notabilis is primarily native to New South Wales, South Australia, and Victoria. This species is commonly found in dry, sandy soils across these regions. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in open woodlands and shrublands. The plant is well adapted to the harsh climatic conditions of its native range. It plays an important ecological role in supporting local wildlife and maintaining soil stability.
